sections.paragraphs:
{{short description|13th-century friar and diplomat}}
'''André de Longjumeau''' (also known as '''Andrew of Longjumeau''' in English) was a 13th-century [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] missionary and diplomat and one of the most active Occidental diplomats in the East in the 13th century. He led two embassies to the [[Mongol Empire|Mongols]]: the first carried letters from [[Pope Innocent IV]] and the second bore gifts and letters from [[Louis IX of France]] to [[Güyük Khan]]. Well acquainted with the [[Middle-East]], he spoke [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and "[[Chaldean Neo-Aramaic|Chaldean]]" (thought to be either [[Syriac language|Syriac]] or [[Persian language|Persian]]).<ref name = "mxpvnk">{{harvnb|Roux|1985|p=96}}</ref>

sections.title: Mission for the holy Crown of Thorns
sections.paragraphs:
[[Image:HolyCrown.JPG|thumb|Andrew went to Constantinople to obtain the [[Crown of Thorns]] bought by [[Louis IX of France|Louis IX]] from [[Baldwin II of Constantinople|Baldwin II]]. It is preserved today in a 19th-century reliquary, in [[Notre Dame de Paris|Notre-Dame Cathedral]], [[Paris]].]]
Andrew's first mission to the East was when he was asked by the French king [[Louis IX of France|Louis IX]] to go and fetch the [[Crown of Thorns]] which had been sold to him by the Latin Emperor of [[Constantinople]] [[Baldwin II of Constantinople|Baldwin II]] in 1238, who was anxious to obtain support for his tottering empire.<ref name = "mxpvnk"/> Andrew was accompanied on this mission by brother Jacques.

sections.title: Papal mission to the Mongols (1245–1247)
sections.paragraphs:
Andrew of Longjumeau led one of four missions dispatched to the Mongols by [[Pope Innocent IV]]. He left [[Lyon]] in the spring of 1245 for the [[Levant]].<ref>Gregory G. Guzman, "Simon of Saint-Quentin and the Dominican Mission to the Mongol Baiju: A Reappraisal" ''Speculum'', Vol. 46, No. 2. (April., 1971), p. 235.</ref> 
He visited Muslim principalities in [[Syria]] and representatives of the [[Nestorianism|Nestorian]] and [[Syriac Orthodox Church|Jacobite]] churches in Persia, finally delivering the papal correspondence to a Mongol general near [[Tabriz]].<ref>[[Igor de Rachewiltz]], ''Papal Envoys to the Great Khans'' (Stanford University Press, 1971), p. 113.</ref> In Tabriz, André de Longjumeau met with a monk from the [[Far East]], named [[Simeon Rabban Ata]], who had been put in charge by the [[Khan (title)|Khan]] of protecting the Christians in the [[Middle-East]].{{sfn|Richard|p=376}}

sections.title: Second mission to the Mongols (1249–1251)
Death
sections.paragraphs:
The date and location of Andrew's death is unknown.<ref name="Dorcy1990">{{cite book|last=Dorcy|first=Sr. Mary Jean|title=St. Dominic's Family: Over 300 Famous Dominicans|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iL-cCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT62|accessdate=15 February 2018|date=24 November 1990|publisher=TAN Books|isbn=9781505103465|page=62}}</ref>

We only know of Andrew through references in other writers: see especially [[William of Rubruck]]'s in ''Recueil de voyages'', iv. (Paris, 1839), pp. 261, 265, 279, 296, 310, 353, 363, 370; Joinville, ed. Francisque Michel (1858, etc.), pp. 142, etc.; Jean Pierre Sarrasin, in same vol., pp. 254–235; [[Guillaume de Nangis|William of Nangis]] in ''Recueil des historiens des Gaules'', xx. 359–367; [[Charles de Rémusat|Rémusat]], ''Mémoires sur les relations politiques des princes chrétiens… avec les… Mongols'' (1822, etc.), p. 52.{{sfn|Beazley|1911|p=973}}
